newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Tsang urges care in using tax for HK property woes.
newsitem.headline: Tsang urges care in using tax for HK property woes.

text.p: The new Hong Kong government should "tread carefully" around the idea of raising taxes to combat property speculation, Financial Secretary Donald Tsang said on Saturday.
"I think we have to tread very carefully in this regard," Tsang told reporters at a press briefing.
Tsang said that applying capital gains taxes on property transactions has not always been effective in other countries where it has been tried.
Hong Kong property prices have surged over the last year, moving the government to consider strong action to combat speculation.

Leung Chun-ying, a property consultant who will hold the property portfolio in the administration of Chief Executive-designate Tung Chee-hwa, is expected to present the findings of a three-month study on the property market soon.
Hong Kong reverts to China at midnight on June 30 after more than 150 years of British colonial rule.
Tsang, who is financial secretary for the British colonial government in Hong Kong, will continue in his post in the new administration.
The financial secretary said that one of the solutions to the problem of rapidly rising real estate prices is to increase the supply of land.

"We have set up a special task force already with the mission to provide a long-term plan, a transparent plant, so that the developers and the potential buyers will have some ideas how much land will be made available," said Tsang.
If speculative activity were to destabilise the market in the short-term, the government would take action, Tsang said.
"If we see speculative activity popping up, the government will not be sitting idly without doing anything about it, he said.
